section.heading: Short title.

content.p: This chapter may be cited as the Residential Landlord and Tenant Act.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the terms defined inNRS 118A.030to118A.175, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Abandoned propertyï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Abandoned propertyï¿½ means property which is left unattended on the premises after the termination of the tenancy, unless the owner of the property has expressed an intent to return for the property.

section.heading: ï¿½Actionï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Actionï¿½ includes counterclaim, crossclaim, third-party claim or any other proceeding in which rights are determined.

section.heading: ï¿½Building, housing and health codesï¿½ defined.

content.p: Health, safety, sanitation or fitness for habitation; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The construction, maintenance, operation, occupancy, use or appearance, ï¿½of any premises or dwelling unit.

section.heading: ï¿½Causeï¿½ defined.

content.p: Nonpayment of rent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Nonpayment of utility charges if the landlord customarily pays such charges and submits a separate bill to the tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Failure of the tenant to comply with: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Valid rules or regulations established pursuant to this chapter; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Valid provisions of the rental agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Condemnation of the dwelling unit.

section.heading: ï¿½Courtï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Courtï¿½ means the district court, Justice Court or other court of competent jurisdiction situated in the county or township wherein the premises are located.

section.heading: ï¿½Dwellingï¿½ and ï¿½dwelling unitï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Dwellingï¿½ or ï¿½dwelling unitï¿½ means a structure or the part of a structure that is occupied as, or designed or intended for occupancy as, a residence or sleeping place by one person who maintains a household or by two or more persons who maintain a common household.

section.heading: ï¿½Excludeï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Excludeï¿½ means to evict or to prohibit entry by locking doors or by otherwise blocking or attempting to block entry, or to make a dwelling unit uninhabitable by interrupting or causing the interruption of electric, gas, water or other essential services.

section.heading: ï¿½Federal workerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Federal workerï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 40.002.

section.heading: ï¿½Landlordï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Landlordï¿½ means a person who provides a dwelling unit for occupancy by another pursuant to a rental agreement.

section.heading: ï¿½Normal wearï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Normal wearï¿½ means that deterioration which occurs without negligence, carelessness or abuse of the premises, equipment or chattels by the tenant, a member of the tenantï¿½s household or other person on the premises with the tenantï¿½s consent.

section.heading: ï¿½Ownerï¿½ defined.

content.p: All or part of the legal title to property, except a trustee under a deed of trust who is not in possession of the property; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
All or part of the beneficial ownership, and a right to present use and enjoyment of the premises.

section.heading: ï¿½Periodic rentï¿½ defined.

content.p: For a tenancy on a week to week basis, the amount payable each week; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a tenancy on an annual basis, the amount payable annually divided by 12.

section.heading: ï¿½Personï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Personï¿½ includes a government, a governmental agency and a political subdivision of a government.

section.heading: ï¿½Premisesï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Premisesï¿½ means a dwelling unit and the structure of which it is a part, facilities, furniture, utilities and appurtenances therein and grounds, areas and facilities held out for the use of tenants.

section.heading: ï¿½Rentï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Rentï¿½ means all periodic payments to be made to the landlord for occupancy of a dwelling unit, including, without limitation, all reasonable and actual late fees set forth in the rental agreement.

section.heading: ï¿½Rental agreementï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Rental agreementï¿½ means any oral or written agreement for the use and occupancy of a dwelling unit or premises.

section.heading: ï¿½Shutdownï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Shutdownï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 40.0035.

section.heading: ï¿½State workerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½State workerï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 40.004.

section.heading: ï¿½Tenantï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Tenantï¿½ means a person entitled under a rental agreement to occupy a dwelling unit to the exclusion of others.

section.heading: ï¿½Tribal workerï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Tribal workerï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 40.0045.

section.heading: Applicability.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, this chapter applies to, regulates and determines rights, obligations and remedies under a rental agreement, wherever made, for a dwelling unit or premises located within this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This chapter does not apply to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Low-rent housing programs operated by public housing authorities and established pursuant to the United States Housing Act of 1937, 42 U.S.C. ï¿½ï¿½ 1437 et seq.; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Occupancy under a contract of sale of a dwelling unit or the property of which it is a part, if the occupant is the purchaser or his or her successor in interest; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Occupancy by a member of a fraternal or social organization in the portion of a structure operated for the benefit of the organization; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Occupancy in a hotel or motel for less than 30 consecutive days unless the occupant clearly manifests an intent to remain for a longer continuous period; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Occupancy by an employee of a landlord whose right to occupancy is solely conditional upon employment in or about the premises; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Occupancy by a person who is guilty of a forcible entry, as defined inNRS 40.230, or a forcible detainer, as defined inNRS 40.240; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Occupancy under an agreement for the purchase and sale of a dwelling unit or the property of which it is a part for a period not to exceed 90 days, if the occupant is the seller or his or her successor in interest.

section.heading: Notice: Definition; service.

content.p: A person has notice of a fact if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person has actual knowledge of it; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person has received a notice or notification of it; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
From all the facts and circumstances the person reasonably should know that it exists. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Written notices to the tenant prescribed by this chapter shall be served in the manner provided byNRS 40.280. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Written notices to the landlord prescribed by this chapter may be delivered or mailed to the place of business of the landlord designated in the rental agreement or to any place held out by the landlord as the place for the receipt of rental payments from the tenant and are effective from the date of delivery or mailing.

section.heading: Rental agreements: Signing; copies; required provisions; disputable presumptions; use of nonconforming agreement unlawful.

content.p: Any written agreement for the use and occupancy of a dwelling unit or premises must be signed by the landlord or his or her agent and the tenant or his or her agent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The landlord shall provide one copy of any written agreement described in subsection 1 to the tenant free of cost at the time the agreement is executed and, upon request of the tenant, provide additional copies of any such agreement to the tenant within a reasonable time. The landlord may charge a reasonable fee for providing the additional copies. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any written rental agreement must contain, but is not limited to, provisions relating to the following subjects: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Duration of the agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Amount of rent and the manner and time of its payment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Occupancy by children or pets. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Services included with the dwelling rental. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Fees which are required and the purposes for which they are required. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Deposits which are required and the conditions for their refund. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Charges which may be required for late or partial payment of rent or for return of any dishonored check. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Inspection rights of the landlord. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A listing of persons or numbers of persons who are to occupy the dwelling. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Respective responsibilities of the landlord and the tenant as to the payment of utility charges. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A signed record of the inventory and condition of the premises under the exclusive custody and control of the tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A summary of the provisions ofNRS 202.470. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Information regarding the procedure pursuant to which a tenant may report to the appropriate authorities: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A nuisance. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A violation of a building, safety or health code or regulation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Information regarding the right of the tenant to engage in the display of the flag of the United States, as set forth inNRS 118A.325. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In addition to the provisions required by subsection 3, any written rental agreement for a single-family residence which is not signed by an authorized agent of the landlord who at the time of signing holds a permit to engage in property management pursuant tochapter 645of NRS must contain a disclosure at the top of the first page of the agreement, in a font size at least two times larger than any other font size in the agreement, which states that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
There are rebuttable presumptions inNRS 205.0813and205.0817that the tenant does not have lawful occupancy of the dwelling unless the agreement: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is notarized or is signed by an authorized agent of the landlord who at the time of signing holds a permit to engage in property management pursuant tochapter 645of NRS; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Includes the current address and telephone number of the landlord or his or her authorized representative; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The agreement is valid and enforceable against the landlord and the tenant regardless of whether the agreement: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is notarized or is signed by an authorized agent of the landlord who at the time of signing holds a permit to engage in property management pursuant tochapter 645of NRS; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Includes the current address and telephone number of the landlord or his or her authorized representative. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The absence of a written agreement raises a disputable presumption that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
There are no restrictions on occupancy by children or pets. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Maintenance and waste removal services are provided without charge to the tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
No charges for partial or late payments of rent or for dishonored checks are paid by the tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Other than normal wear, the premises will be returned in the same condition as when the tenancy began. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

It is unlawful for a landlord or any person authorized to enter into a rental agreement on his or her behalf to use any written agreement which does not conform to the provisions of this section, and any provision in an agreement which contravenes the provisions of this section is void. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½single-family residenceï¿½ means a structure that is comprised of not more than four units. The term does not include a manufactured home as defined inNRS 118B.015.

section.heading: Rental agreements: Payment of rent; term of tenancy; late fee.

content.p: Rent is payable without demand or notice at the time and place agreed upon by the parties. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Unless the rental agreement establishes a definite term, the tenancy is from week to week in the case of a tenant who pays weekly rent and in all other cases the tenancy is from month to month. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In the absence of an agreement, either written or oral: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Rent is payable at the beginning of the tenancy; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Rent for the use and occupancy of a dwelling is the fair rental value for the use and occupancy. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A landlord may charge a reasonable late fee for the late payment of rent as set forth in the rental agreement, but: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In a tenancy that is longer than week to week, no late fee may be charged or imposed until at least 3 calendar days after the date that rent is due; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Such a late fee must not exceed 5 percent of the amount of the periodic rent; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The maximum amount of the late fee must not be increased based upon a late fee that was previously imposed.

section.heading: Rental agreements: Prohibited provisions.

content.p: A rental agreement shall not provide that the tenant: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Agrees to pay the landlordï¿½s attorneyï¿½s fees, except that the agreement may provide that reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees may be awarded to the prevailing party in the event of court action; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Agrees to the exculpation or limitation of any liability of the landlord arising under law or to indemnify the landlord for that liability or the costs connected therewith if the liability is based upon an act or omission of the landlord or any agent or employee of the landlord; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Agrees to give the landlord a different notice of termination than that required to be given by the landlord to the tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any provision prohibited by subsection 1 is void as contrary to public policy and the tenant may recover any actual damages incurred through the inclusion of the prohibited provision.

section.heading: Rental agreements: Unconscionability.

content.p: If the court as a matter of law finds that a rental agreement or any of its provisions was unconscionable when made, the court may refuse to enforce the agreement, enforce the remainder of the agreement without the unconscionable provision or limit the application of any unconscionable provision to avoid an unconscionable result. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If unconscionability is put in issue by a party or by the court upon its own motion, the parties shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity to present evidence as to the setting, purpose and effect of the rental agreement or settlement to aid the court in making its determination.

section.heading: ï¿½Security depositï¿½ defined.

content.p: Any payment, deposit, fee or charge that is to be used for any of the following purposes is a ï¿½security depositï¿½ and is governed by the provisions of this section andNRS 118A.242and118A.244: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Remedying any default of the tenant in the payments of rent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Repairing damages to the premises other than normal wear caused by the tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Cleaning the dwelling unit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Security depositï¿½ does not include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any payment, deposit or fee to secure an option to purchase the premises; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any payment to a corporation qualified under the laws of this State as a surety, guarantor or obligator for a premium paid to secure a surety bond or a similar bond, guarantee or insurance coverage for purposes of securing a tenantï¿½s obligations to a landlord as described inNRS 118A.242.

section.heading: Security deposit: Limitation on amount or value; surety bond in lieu of security deposit; duties and liability of landlord; damages; disputing itemized accounting of security deposit; prohibited provisions.

content.p: The landlord may not demand or receive a security deposit or a surety bond, or a combination thereof, including the last monthï¿½s rent, whose total amount or value exceeds 3 monthsï¿½ periodic rent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In lieu of paying all or part of the security deposit required by the landlord, a tenant may, if the landlord consents, purchase a surety bond to secure the tenantï¿½s obligation to the landlord under the rental agreement to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Remedy any default of the tenant in the payment of rent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Repair damages to the premises other than normal wear and tear. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Clean the dwelling unit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The landlord: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is not required to accept a surety bond purchased by the tenant in lieu of paying all or part of the security deposit; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
May not require a tenant to purchase a surety bond in lieu of paying all or part of the security deposit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon termination of the tenancy by either party for any reason, the landlord may claim of the security deposit or surety bond, or a combination thereof, only such amounts as are reasonably necessary to remedy any default of the tenant in the payment of rent, to repair damages to the premises caused by the tenant other than normal wear and to pay the reasonable costs of cleaning the premises. The landlord shall provide the tenant with an itemized, written accounting of the disposition of the security deposit or surety bond, or a combination thereof, and return any remaining portion of the security deposit to the tenant no later than 30 days after the termination of the tenancy by handing it to the tenant personally at the place where the rent is paid, or by mailing it to the tenant at the tenantï¿½s present address or, if that address is unknown, at the tenantï¿½s last known address. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a tenant disputes an item contained in an itemized written accounting received from a landlord pursuant to subsection 4, the tenant may send a written response disputing the item to the surety. If the tenant sends the written response within 30 days after receiving the itemized written accounting, the surety shall not report the claim of the landlord to a credit reporting agency unless the surety obtains a judgment against the tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the landlord fails or refuses to return the remainder of a security deposit within 30 days after the end of a tenancy, the landlord is liable to the tenant for damages: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In an amount equal to the entire security deposit; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a sum to be fixed by the court of not more than the amount of the entire security deposit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In determining the sum, if any, to be awarded under paragraph
of subsection 6, the court shall consider: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Whether the landlord acted in good faith; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The course of conduct between the landlord and the tenant; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The degree of harm to the tenant caused by the landlordï¿½s conduct. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except for an agreement which provides for a nonrefundable charge for cleaning, in a reasonable amount, no rental agreement may contain any provision characterizing any security deposit under this section as nonrefundable or any provision waiving or modifying a tenantï¿½s rights under this section. Any such provision is void as contrary to public policy. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The claim of a tenant to a security deposit to which the tenant is entitled under this chapter takes precedence over the claim of any creditor of the landlord.

section.heading: Notice or transfer of security deposit or surety bond to tenant and successor in interest required upon transfer of dwelling unit.

content.p: Upon termination of the landlordï¿½s interest in the dwelling unit, whether by sale, assignment, death, appointment of receiver or otherwise, the landlord or his or her agent shall, within a reasonable time, do one of the following, which relieves the landlord of further liability with respect to the security deposit or surety bond, or a combination thereof: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Notify the tenant in writing of the name, address and telephone number of the landlordï¿½s successor in interest, and that the landlord has transferred to his or her successor in interest the portion of the security deposit or surety bond, or combination thereof, remaining after making any deductions allowed underNRS 118A.242. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Return to the tenant the portion of the security deposit remaining after making any deductions allowed underNRS 118A.242. ï¿½The successor has the rights, obligations and liabilities of the former landlord as to any portion of the security deposit owed under this section orNRS 118A.242at the time of transfer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The landlord shall, before he or she records a deed transferring any dwelling unit: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Transfer to his or her successor, in writing, the portion of any tenantï¿½s security deposit or other money held by the landlord which remains after making any deductions allowed underNRS 118A.242; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Notify his or her successor in writing that the landlord has returned all such security deposits or portions thereof to the tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Upon the termination of a landlordï¿½s interest in the dwelling unit, whether by sale, assignment, death, appointment of receiver or otherwise, the successor in interest: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Shall accept the tenantï¿½s security deposit or surety bond, or a combination thereof; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Shall not require any additional security deposit or surety bond, or a combination thereof, from the tenant during the term of the rental agreement.

section.heading: Receipts for security deposit, surety bond, rent and other payments.

content.p: The landlord shall deliver to the tenant upon the tenantï¿½s request a signed written receipt for the security deposit or surety bond, or a combination thereof, and any other payments, deposits or fees, including rent, paid by the tenant and received by the landlord. The tenant may refuse to make rent payments until the landlord tenders the requested receipt.

section.heading: Disclosure of names and addresses of managers and owners; emergency telephone number; service of process.

content.p: The landlord, or any person authorized to enter into a rental agreement on his or her behalf, shall disclose to the tenant in writing at or before the commencement of the tenancy: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name and address of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The persons authorized to manage the premises; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person within this State authorized to act for and on behalf of the landlord for the purpose of service of process and receiving notices and demands; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The principal or corporate owner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A telephone number at which a responsible person who resides in the county or within 60 miles of where the premises are located may be called in case of emergency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The information required to be furnished by this section must be kept current, and this section is enforceable against any successor landlord or manager of the premises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A party who enters into a rental agreement on behalf of the landlord and fails to comply with this section is an agent of the landlord for purposes of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Service of process and receiving notices and demands; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Performing the obligations of the landlord under law and under the rental agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In any action against a landlord which involves his or her rental property, service of process upon the manager of the property or a person described in paragraph

of subsection 1 shall be deemed to be service upon the landlord. The obligations of the landlord devolve upon the persons authorized to enter into a rental agreement on his or her behalf. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not limit or remove the liability of an undisclosed landlord.

section.heading: Alternative method of disclosure.

content.p: In each dwelling structure containing an elevator, place a printed or typewritten notice containing the information required by that section in every elevator and in one other conspicuous place; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In each dwelling structure not containing an elevator, place a printed or typewritten notice containing that information in at least two conspicuous places. ï¿½The notices shall be kept current and reasonable efforts shall be made to maintain them in a visible position and legible condition.

section.heading: Disclosure of foreclosure proceedings on premises to prospective tenant; willful violation constitutes deceptive trade practice by landlord.

content.p: A landlord shall disclose in writing to a prospective tenant if the property to be leased or rented is the subject of any foreclosure proceedings. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A willful violation of subsection 1 constitutes a deceptive trade practice for the purposes ofNRS 598.0903to598.0999, inclusive.

section.heading: Delivery of possession of premises.

content.p: At the commencement of the rental term the landlord shall deliver possession of the premises to the tenant in compliance with the rental agreement and in a habitable condition as provided in this chapter.

section.heading: Habitability of dwelling unit; prohibition against fees or other charges for performance of repairs, maintenance tasks or other work that is duty of landlord.

content.p: The landlord shall at all times during the tenancy maintain the dwelling unit in a habitable condition. A dwelling unit is not habitable if it violates provisions of housing or health codes concerning the health, safety, sanitation or fitness for habitation of the dwelling unit or if it substantially lacks: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Effective waterproofing and weather protection of the roof and exterior walls, including windows and doors. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Plumbing facilities which conformed to applicable law when installed and which are maintained in good working order. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A water supply approved under applicable law, which is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Furnished to appropriate fixtures; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Connected to a sewage disposal system approved under applicable law and maintained in good working order to the extent that the system can be controlled by the landlord. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Adequate heating facilities which conformed to applicable law when installed and are maintained in good working order. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Electrical lighting, outlets, wiring and electrical equipment which conformed to applicable law when installed and are maintained in good working order. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An adequate number of appropriate receptacles for garbage and rubbish in clean condition and good repair at the commencement of the tenancy. The landlord shall arrange for the removal of garbage and rubbish from the premises unless the parties by written agreement provide otherwise. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Building, grounds, appurtenances and all other areas under the landlordï¿½s control at the time of the commencement of the tenancy in every part clean, sanitary and reasonably free from all accumulations of debris, filth, rubbish, garbage, rodents, insects and vermin. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Floors, walls, ceilings, stairways and railings maintained in good repair. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Ventilating, air-conditioning and other facilities and appliances, including elevators, maintained in good repair if supplied or required to be supplied by the landlord. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The landlord and tenant may agree that the tenant is to perform specified repairs, maintenance tasks and minor remodeling only if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The agreement of the parties is entered into in good faith; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The agreement does not diminish the obligations of the landlord to other tenants in the premises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An agreement pursuant to subsection 2 is not entered into in good faith if the landlord has a duty under subsection 1 to perform the specified repairs, maintenance tasks or minor remodeling and the tenant enters into the agreement because the landlord or his or her agent has refused to perform them. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 5, the landlord shall not require a tenant to pay any fee or other charge for the performance of any repairs, maintenance tasks or other work for which the landlord has a duty under subsection 1 to perform, including, without limitation, any fee or other charge to cover the costs of any deductible or copayment under a policy of insurance for home protection or service contract for the performance of any such repairs, maintenance tasks or other work. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The landlord may require a tenant to pay any fee or other charge for the performance of any repairs, maintenance tasks or other work necessary for a condition caused by the tenantï¿½s own deliberate or negligent act or omission or that of a member of his or her household or other person on the premises with his or her consent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Insurance for home protectionï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 690B.100. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Service contractï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 690C.080.

section.heading: Advance notice of increase of rent.

content.p: The landlord may not increase the rent payable by a tenant unless the landlord serves the tenant with a written notice, 60 days or, in the case of any periodic tenancy of less than 1 month, 30 days in advance of the first rental payment to be increased, advising the tenant of the increase.

section.heading: Basic obligations; exception to term of rental agreement requiring payment of rent at specified time in connection with shutdown.

content.p: A tenant shall, as basic obligations under this chapter: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Use in a reasonable manner all electrical, plumbing, sanitary, heating, ventilating, air-conditioning and other facilities and appliances, including elevators, in the premises; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Not deliberately or negligently render the premises uninhabitable or destroy, deface, damage, impair or remove any part of the premises or knowingly permit any person to do so; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Conduct himself or herself and require other persons on the premises with his or her consent to conduct themselves in a manner that will not disturb a neighborï¿½s peaceful enjoyment of the premises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided inNRS 118A.315: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any term of a rental agreement requiring the payment of rent at a specified time pursuant toNRS 118A.210is unenforceable against a tenant who is a federal worker, tribal worker, state worker or household member of such a worker during a shutdown. As used in this paragraph, ï¿½household memberï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 40.0025. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the terms of a rental agreement require the payment of rent at a specified time, the landlord shall accept payment of rent for the period in which a federal or state agency or tribal government was experiencing a shutdown from such a tenant for a period not to exceed 30 days after the end of the shutdown.

section.heading: Petition by landlord for relief from certain requirements relating to shutdown.

content.p: If a shutdown continues for a period of 30 days or more, the landlord may petition the court for relief from the requirements prescribed in subsection 4 ofNRS 40.251and subsection 2 ofNRS 118A.310on the basis that the requirements impose an undue hardship on the landlord. In determining whether to grant relief from these requirements, the court may consider, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The mortgage on the property and the risk of foreclosure; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any additional financial responsibilities of the landlord, including, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Child support or alimony; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Motor vehicle payments, student loans, medical bills and payment plans; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any costs associated with the continued operation of a business of the landlord. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the court grants relief pursuant to subsection 1: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The parties may modify the terms of the rental agreement; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The landlord may terminate the rental agreement and commence eviction proceedings in accordance with the provisions ofchapter 40of NRS.

section.heading: Rules or regulations of landlord.

content.p: The landlord, from time to time, may adopt rules or regulations concerning the tenantï¿½s use and occupancy of the premises. Such a rule or regulation is enforceable against the tenant only if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Its purpose is to promote the convenience, safety or welfare of the landlord or tenants in the premises, preserve the landlordï¿½s property from abusive use or make a fair distribution of services and facilities held out for the tenants generally; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
It is sufficiently explicit in its prohibition, direction or limitation of the tenantï¿½s conduct fairly to inform the tenant of what must or must not be done to comply; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
It does not affect, before the end of the duration of the rental agreement, any right the tenant may have under the rental agreement to keep a pet; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The tenant has notice of the rule or regulation at the time the tenant enters into the rental agreement or after the rule or regulation is adopted by the landlord. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A rule or regulation adopted after the tenant enters into the rental agreement which works a material modification of the bargain is enforceable against a tenant: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Who expressly consents to the rule or regulation in writing; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Who has 30 daysï¿½ advance written notice of the rule or regulation.

section.heading: Right of tenant to display flag of the United States in certain areas; conditions and limitations on exercise of right.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a landlord or an agent or employee of a landlord shall not prohibit a tenant from engaging in the display of the flag of the United States within such physical portion of the premises as that tenant has a right to occupy and use exclusively. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Apply to the display of the flag of the United States for commercial advertising purposes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Preclude a landlord or an agent or employee of a landlord from adopting rules that reasonably restrict the placement and manner of the display of the flag of the United States by a tenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In any action commenced to enforce the provisions of this section, the prevailing party is entitled to recover reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½display of the flag of the United Statesï¿½ means a flag of the United States that is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Made of cloth, fabric or paper; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Displayed from a pole or staff or in a window; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Displayed in a manner that is consistent with 4 U.S.C. Chapter 1. ï¿½The term does not include a depiction or emblem of the flag of the United States that is made of balloons, flora, lights, paint, paving materials, roofing, siding or any other similar building, decorative or landscaping component.

section.heading: Landlordï¿½s access to dwelling unit.

content.p: A tenant shall not unreasonably withhold consent for the landlord peaceably to enter into the dwelling unit to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Inspect the premises; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Supply necessary or agreed services; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Exhibit the dwelling unit to prospective or actual purchasers, mortgagees, tenants, workers, contractors or other persons with a bona fide interest in inspecting the premises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The landlord may enter the dwelling unit without consent of the tenant in case of emergency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The landlord shall not abuse the right of access or use it to harass the tenant. Except in case of emergency, the landlord shall give the tenant at least 24 hoursï¿½ notice of intent to enter and may enter only at reasonable times during normal business hours unless the tenant expressly consents to shorter notice or to entry during nonbusiness hours with respect to the particular entry. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The landlord has no other right of access except: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Pursuant to court order; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Where the tenant has abandoned or surrendered the premises; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Where permitted underNRS 118A.440.

section.heading: Landlord prohibited from employing certain persons without work card under certain circumstances; requirements governing issuance and renewal of work card; exceptions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 6, a landlord of dwelling units intended and operated exclusively for persons 55 years of age and older may not employ any person who will work 36 hours or more per week and who will have access to all dwelling units to perform work on the premises unless the person has obtained a work card issued pursuant to subsection 2 by the sheriff of the county in which the dwelling units are located and renewed that work card as necessary. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The sheriff of a county shall issue a work card to each person who is required by this section to obtain a work card and who complies with the requirements established by the sheriff for the issuance of such a card. A work card issued pursuant to this section must be renewed: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Every 5 years; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Whenever the person changes his or her employment to perform work for an employer other than the employer for which the personï¿½s current work card was issued. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, if the sheriff of a county requires an applicant for a work card to be investigated: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The applicant must submit with his or her application a complete set of his or her fingerprints and written permission authorizing the sheriff to forward the fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for its report. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The sheriff shall submit the fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation to determine the criminal history of the applicant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The sheriff may issue a temporary work card pending the determination of the criminal history of the applicant by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The sheriff of a county shall not require an investigation of the criminal history of an employee or independent contractor of an agency or facility governed byNRS 449.122to449.125, inclusive, and449.174who has had his or her fingerprints submitted to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History pursuant toNRS 449.123for an investigation of his or her criminal history within the immediately preceding 6 months. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The sheriff shall not issue a work card to any person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been convicted of a category A, B or C felony or of a crime in another state which would be a category A, B or C felony if committed in this State; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been convicted of a sexual offense; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Has been convicted of a crime against any person who is 60 years of age or older or against a vulnerable person for which an additional term of imprisonment may be imposed pursuant toNRS 193.167or the laws of any other jurisdiction; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been convicted of a battery punishable as a gross misdemeanor; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Within the immediately preceding 5 years: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been convicted of a theft; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been convicted of a violation of any state or federal law regulating the possession, distribution or use of a controlled substance. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The following persons are not required to obtain a work card pursuant to this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who holds a permit to engage in property management pursuant tochapter 645of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An independent contractor. As used in this paragraph, ï¿½independent contractorï¿½ means a person who performs services for a fixed price according to the personï¿½s own methods and without subjection to the supervision or control of the landlord, except as to the results of the work, and not as to the means by which the services are accomplished. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An offender in the course and scope of his or her employment in a work program directed by the warden, sheriff, administrator or other person responsible for administering a prison, jail or other detention facility. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person performing work through a court-assigned restitution or community-service program. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the sheriff does not issue a work card to a person because the information received from the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History indicates that the person has been convicted of a crime listed in subsection 5 and the person believes that the information provided by the Central Repository is incorrect, the person may immediately inform the sheriff. If the sheriff is so informed, the sheriff shall give the person at least 30 days in which to correct the information before terminating the temporary work card issued pursuant to subsection 3. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Sexual offenseï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 179D.097. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Vulnerable personï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 200.5092.

section.heading: Right of tenant or cotenant to terminate lease due to physical or mental disability or death.

content.p: Notwithstanding any provision in a lease of a dwelling to the contrary, if a physical or mental condition of a tenant requires the relocation of the tenant from his or her dwelling because of a need for care or treatment that cannot be provided in the dwelling and the tenant is 60 years of age or older or has a physical or mental disability: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
That tenant may terminate the lease by giving the landlord 30 daysï¿½ written notice within 60 days after the tenant relocates; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A cotenant of that tenant may terminate the lease by giving the landlord 30 daysï¿½ written notice within 60 days after the tenant relocates if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The cotenant became a tenant of the dwelling before the date on which the lease was signed by the tenant who is relocating and the cotenant is 60 years of age or older or has a physical or mental disability; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The cotenant became a tenant of the dwelling on or after the date on which the lease was signed by the tenant who is relocating. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Notwithstanding any provision in a lease of a dwelling to the contrary, upon the death of the spouse or cotenant of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A tenant who is 60 years of age or older; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A tenant who has a physical or mental disability, ï¿½the tenant may terminate the lease by giving the landlord 60 daysï¿½ written notice within 3 months after the death. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The written notice provided to a landlord pursuant to subsection 1 or 2 must set forth the facts which demonstrate that the tenant or cotenant is entitled to terminate the lease. If the tenant or cotenant is terminating the lease pursuant to subsection 1, the tenant or cotenant shall include reasonable verification: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Of the existence of the physical or mental condition of the tenant; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
That the physical or mental condition requires the relocation of the tenant from his or her dwelling because of a need for care or treatment that cannot be provided in the dwelling. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section does not give a landlord the right to terminate a lease solely because of the death of one of the tenants. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½cotenantï¿½ means a tenant who, pursuant to a lease, is entitled to occupy a dwelling that another tenant who is 60 years of age or older or who has a physical or mental disability is also entitled to occupy pursuant to the same lease.

section.heading: Right of tenant or cotenant to terminate lease due to domestic violence, harassment, sexual assault or stalking.

content.p: Notwithstanding any provision in a rental agreement to the contrary, if a tenant, cotenant or household member is the victim of domestic violence, harassment, sexual assault or stalking, the tenant or any cotenant may terminate the rental agreement by giving the landlord written notice of termination effective at the end of the current rental period or 30 days after the notice is provided to the landlord, whichever occurs sooner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In the case of a termination of a rental agreement pursuant to this section on the grounds that a tenant, cotenant or household member is a victim of domestic violence, the written notice provided to a landlord pursuant to subsection 1 must describe the reason for the termination of the rental agreement and be accompanied by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A copy of an order for protection against domestic violence issued to the tenant, cotenant or household member who is the victim of domestic violence; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A copy of a written report from a law enforcement agency indicating that the tenant, cotenant or household member notified the law enforcement agency of the domestic violence; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A copy of a written affidavit in the form prescribed pursuant toNRS 118A.347and signed by a qualified third party acting in his or her official capacity stating that the tenant, cotenant or household member is a victim of domestic violence and identifying the adverse party. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In the case of a termination of a rental agreement pursuant to this section on the grounds that a tenant, cotenant or household member is a victim of harassment, sexual assault or stalking, the written notice provided to a landlord pursuant to subsection 1 must describe the reason for the termination of the rental agreement and be accompanied by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A copy of a written report from a law enforcement agency indicating that the tenant, cotenant or household member notified the law enforcement agency of the harassment, sexual assault or stalking, as applicable; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A copy of a temporary or extended order issued pursuant toNRS 200.378or200.591, as applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A tenant or cotenant may terminate a rental agreement pursuant to this section only if the actions, events or circumstances that resulted in the tenant, cotenant or household member becoming a victim of domestic violence, harassment, sexual assault or stalking occurred within the 90 days immediately preceding the written notice of termination to the landlord. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A tenant or cotenant who terminates a rental agreement pursuant to this section is only liable, if solely or jointly liable for purposes of the rental agreement, for any rent owed or required to be paid through the date of termination and any other outstanding obligations. If the tenant or cotenant has prepaid rent that would apply for the rental period in which the rental agreement is terminated, the landlord may retain the prepaid rent and no refund is due to the tenant or cotenant unless the amount of the prepaid rent exceeds what is owed for that rental period. Except as otherwise provided inNRS 118A.242, if the tenant or cotenant has paid a security deposit, the deposit must not be withheld for the early termination of the rental agreement if the rental agreement is terminated pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person who is named as the adverse party may be civilly liable for all economic losses incurred by a landlord for the early termination of a rental agreement pursuant to this section, including, without limitation, unpaid rent, fees relating to early termination, costs for the repair of any damages to the dwelling and any reductions in or waivers of rent previously extended to the tenant or cotenant who terminates the rental agreement pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A landlord shall not provide to an adverse party any information concerning the whereabouts of a tenant, cotenant or household member if the tenant or cotenant provided notice pursuant to subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a tenant or cotenant provided notice pursuant to subsection 1, the tenant, the cotenant or a household member may require the landlord to install a new lock onto the dwelling if the tenant, cotenant or household member pays the cost of installing the new lock. A landlord complies with the requirements of this subsection by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Rekeying the lock if the lock is in good working condition; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Replacing the entire locking mechanism with a new locking mechanism of equal or superior quality. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A landlord who installs a new lock pursuant to subsection 8 may retain a copy of the new key. Notwithstanding any provision in a rental agreement to the contrary, the landlord shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Refuse to provide a key which unlocks the new lock to an adverse party. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Refuse to provide to an adverse party, whether or not that party is a tenant, cotenant or household member, access to the dwelling to reclaim property unless a law enforcement officer is present. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section shall not be construed to limit a landlordï¿½s right to terminate a rental agreement for reasons unrelated to domestic violence, harassment, sexual assault or stalking. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the termination of a rental agreement pursuant to this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Must not be disclosed, described or characterized as an early termination by a current landlord to a prospective landlord; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is not required to be disclosed as an early termination by a tenant or cotenant to a prospective landlord. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Adverse partyï¿½ means a person who is named in an order for protection against domestic violence, harassment, sexual assault or stalking, a written report from a law enforcement agency or a written statement from a qualified third party and who is alleged to be the cause of the early termination of a rental agreement pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Cotenantï¿½ means a tenant who, pursuant to a rental agreement, is entitled to occupy a dwelling that another tenant is also entitled to occupy pursuant to the same rental agreement. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Domestic violenceï¿½ means the commission of any act described inNRS 33.018. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Harassmentï¿½ means a violation ofNRS 200.571. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Household memberï¿½ means any person who is related by blood or marriage and is actually residing with a tenant or cotenant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Qualified third partyï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A psychiatrist licensed to practice medicine in this State and certified by the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology, Inc. or the American Osteopathic Board of Neurology and Psychiatry of the American Osteopathic Association; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A registered nurse holding a masterï¿½s degree in the field of psychiatric nursing and licensed to practice professional nursing in this State; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Is employed by an agency or service which advises persons regarding domestic violence or refers them to persons or agencies where their request and needs can be met and who is licensed to provide health care pursuant to the provisions of title 54 of NRS, or is a member of the board of directors or serves as the executive director of an agency or service which advises persons regarding domestic violence or refers them to persons or agencies where their request and needs can be met; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Has received training relating to domestic violence; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) Is a resident of this State; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any member of the clergy of a church or religious society or denomination that is recognized as exempt under section 501
of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, 26 U.S.C. ï¿½ 501

, who has been chosen, elected or appointed in conformity with the constitution, canons, rites, regulations or discipline of the church or religious society or denomination and who is a resident of this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Sexual assaultï¿½ means a violation ofNRS 200.366. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Stalkingï¿½ means a violation ofNRS 200.575.

section.heading: Form of affidavit for written notice terminating lease due to domestic violence.
